Collins}} [[File:canoncollins.jpg|alt=|thumb|upright|right|Canon Collins at an [[anti-nuclear]] rally in Trafalgar Square, London in February 1961]] '''John Collins''' (1905–1982) was an [[Anglican]] priest who was active in several radical political movements in the [[United Kingdom]]. Educated at [[Cranbrook School, Kent|Cranbrook School]], [[Kent]] and the [[University of Cambridge]], Collins served as a chaplain in the [[Royal Air Force]] during [[World War II]] and was radicalised by the experience. In 1946, he founded the organization [[Christian Action]] to work for reconciliation with [[Germany]]. He was appointed as a [[Canon (priest)|canon]] of [[St Paul's Cathedral]], [[London]] in 1948, an office he held for 33 years. Shortly afterwards he became disturbed by the newly developing [[apartheid]] system in [[South Africa]]. In 1951, Collins was one of the four founders of the charity [[War on Want]] which fights global poverty. In 1956, he committed Christian Action to raising funds for the defence of anti-apartheid activists accused of treason in South Africa and this gave rise to the [[Defence and Aid Fund for Southern Africa]]. The fund raised over £75,000 to help defend the accused during the [[Treason Trial]] Collins was strongly opposed to the spread of [[nuclear weapon]]s and was one of many on the [[Left-wing|left]] in Britain who believed that it was unnecessary and wrong for Britain to own such weapons. He was one of the founders of the [[Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament]]. He was also a member of the [[Anglican Pacifist Fellowship]], working with the Reverend [[Sidney Hinkes]] on anti-nuclear campaigns. The [[Canon Collins Educational & Legal Assistance Trust]], formerly known as Canon Collins Trust for Southern Africa (CCETSA) is a [[Charitable organization|charity]] founded in 1981. It was set up as the [[Defence and Aid Fund for Southern Africa]] and Collins was its first chairman. In the days of apartheid it provided money to help South African and [[Namibia]]n refugee students gain the [[higher education]] in the United Kingdom and in independent African states. It now provides scholarships for students within South Africa and in other African countries. ==Family== Collins married [[Diana Collins|Diana Clavering Elliot]] (1917–2003) in 1939; they had four sons. Diana Collins was knighted in 1999 as a [[Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire]]. ==External links== *[http://www.canoncollins.org.uk/johncollins.html Collins' biography on the Canon Collins Educational & Legal Assistance Trust website] *[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2003%2F05%2F27%2Fdb2701.xml Obituary of Diana Collins in the ''Daily Telegraph''] *[http://www.cnduk.org Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament website] {{S-start}} {{succession box | title=[[CND|Chair of CND]]| before= Newly founded | after=[[Olive Gibbs]]| years=1958–1964}} {{S-end}} {{Cranbrook}} {{Persondata | name = Collins, John | alternative names = | short description = | date of birth = 1905 | place of birth = | date of death = 1982 | place of death = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Collins, John}} [[Category:1905 births]] [[Category:1982 deaths]] [[Category:Royal Air Force chaplains]] [[Category:People educated at Cranbrook School, Kent]] [[Category:British anti–nuclear weapons activists]] [[Category:Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament]]
